summary:
Tilen Lebar (b. 1993 in Murska Sobota) is a Slovene-Dutch composer, improviser and saxophonist based in The Hague, The Netherlands. 
After finishing his studies at Conservatoire for Music and Ballet in Maribor with Peter Kruder, he has continued and completed a Master's Degree in Saxophone under mentorship of Miha Rogina and Matjaž Drevenšek at the Academy of Music, University of Ljubljana. 
Tilen studied in the composition class of Uroš Rojko at the University of Ljubljana and successfully finished his Master Composition studies at Royal Conservatoire in The Hague with Guus Janssen, Peter Adriaansz and Cornelis De Bondt as well as his artistic saxophone 
studies in class of Raaf Hekkema.
He is actively participating in the field of the contemporary music performance, improvised music scene and interdisciplinary arts, baroque music performances and regularly cooperates with Zavod Sploh, KUD Mreza, KID PiNA, Ensemble Szene Instrumental, The Styrian Improvisers Orchestra, Inexhaustible Editions, Pergolesi Ensemble and Studio Loos. 
His sound world reveals a great knowledge of individual instrumental extended techniques as well as contemplated colours, detailed structures in sound tinctures and a thorough knowledge of the tradition of contemporary Western art music and various experimental fields. He had performances on festivals as ISCM World Music Days, Gaudeamus Muziekweek, Leicht uber Linz, New Music Forum, ISC World Saxophone Congress, Opera Forward Festival, Andriessen Festival, etc.
On the 67th International Rostrum of Composers his work ‘Staticotion’ for accordion & electronics was a recommended in the general as well as in the under’30 categories. During his studies at the Univesity of Ljubljana he received a Prešeren’s prize by the Academy of Music University of Ljubljana for his portrait 
concert ‘Layering time.’ In The Netherlands he received an international RKST21 award by Orkest De Ereprijs for his work ‘Thought Echo.’ He was a recipient of a scholarship by the Ministry of Culture Republic of Slovenia for his postgraduate studies at the Royal Conservatoire in The Hague. 
His collaborations included ensembles as Asamisimasa from Oslo, Oerknal, Slagwerk Den Haag, Ensemble Contrechamps, institutions as Experimental studio of SWR Freiburg, The Residentie Orkest, Orkest de Ereprijs, Dutch National Opera & Ballet and conductors such as Clark Rundell, Andrew HilaryGrams and Gregory Charette.
His scores are published by Donemus – Publishing House of Contemporary Classical Music and the Society of Slovene Composers (DSS).
